Site Mirroring
Site mirroring can encompass multiple redundancy strategies that you will explore in this section. Site mirroring refers to the process of keeping the backup site updated so it is ready to assume the workload in the event of a primary data center failure. Site mirroring provides an identical copy of the original site’s data and applications operating in standby at a remote site. By implementing a mirroring strategy, you can be better prepared to survive an outage event with little or no impact on your operations

comments.content: Only reason I would go with site mirroring is because in an active/active environment, the goal is for the end user to not experience any type of disruption of service. And it states the "purpose of the plan is to recover business as soon as possible". Again, in an active/active you wouldn't need to "recover business" because the goal is for the end user to not know a failure has happened. In site mirroring, you're talking about a disruption of service while you are bringing the mirrored site online.

discussion.content: This is the best example of how vague these questions can be. While active/active and site mirroring are good answers, it's difficult to understand what the exact problem is. The questions says "A company is interested in DRP"... Site mirroring typically is copying the site to a different geographical area. DR is such a broad term because it can mean fixing a server in your cluster on location or it can mean moving the entire IT operations to a hot site location. So the question is absolutely terrible as it gives zero specifics about what incident they are concerned about. In my opinion, if it involves moving to another site then site mirroring is the answer but if it's an issue located inside the on-site data center, then active/active can be the correct answer. Unfortunately, you're just going to have to flip a coin on this.
